People say it's the worst in the series. Maybe. But is it a bad game? No.   NOTE: Didn't do multiplayer or PvP much = ignored in this review. (sorry)  I enjoyed SotfS A TON! As you can see I wrapped up a lot of hours into it, and only few games can achieve that for me. This one did it. So let's have a quick look.  GRAPHICS - It's not too bad but it's not great either. But Dark Souls was never about graphics, was it?  GAMEPLAY - Very solid, hitboxes could use some work, sometimes you just end up stabbed even though you've clearly rolled away.  CONTROLS - As a keyboard/mouse user I've definitely used them even though the store page strongly recommends controller. The default setup is horrendous, however it's not too hard to tweak it to suit you. As it is completely tweakable. I HEAVILY recommend disabling double-clicking as the game responses to your click are then much slower. Also, the option is bugged and you have to switch it on and off every game restart. So get used to it if you're willing to stay for long.  STORY - I didn't follow it too much, but it looks like you're some kind of an undead, hollow, who needs to seek souls in order to lift the curse. And so you're told to meet the king of Drangleic, the kingdom we are in pretty much the entire game.  ANIMATIONS - Solid and fun to look at.  ITEMS - There's a great variety of items, I've been told there's a lot more than in Dark Souls 1.   SOUND/MUSIC - Great soundtrack. Some sounds do sound a bit old. Breaking for example, sounds very low quality to me. But it's good enough.  OVERALL - As someone who played really only through SotfS, I say it's an epic game, I've been really enjoying my time on it and I can totally recommend it!!  9/10

If you absolutely loved Dark Souls for every aspect of it, do not get this game. You WILL be disappointed and upset.   If you loved Dark Souls because of it's artstyle, do not get this game. When I first walked into the Heide's Tower of Flame area I thought I had started playing a Kirby game or something.  If you loved Dark Souls because it presented a hard but fair and enjoyable challenge, do not get this game. I love Dark Souls 1 because it manages to be a single player game while at the same time presenting a really fun and decent challenge. And it did so with out relying on any cheap or annoying gimmicks. The same cannot be said for this game. It will repeatedly put you against the same dark magic spewing miniboss time and time again. Somebody in the lighting department decided huehue, DARK Souls, let's make certain areas pitch black DARK. Just to make the player use a torch lighting mechanic that adds nothing to the gameplay what so ever. You will repeatedly lose maximum health with each death that cannot be regained without using this game's equivalent of humanity (did I mention that they completely trashed the old humanity system?).   Farming has been nerfed, now if you kill any enemy a certain number of times they will dissapear entirely from the game, only to return if you use and item that raises the area to the next New game level (NG+. NG++, and so on).  On the topic of health and cheap tactics, all healing has been nerfed. The estus flask heals you much slower, and the only alternative you have to it besides miracles, soul gems, heal even slower. Humanity does not exist in this game so don't even consider relying on that. Healing speed is not the only nerf the estus flask has gotten. The Kindling mechanic is gone. You now start with 1 swig in your flask and can have a maximum of 12. The upgrade process only increases it by 1 at a time. Oh, and you still have to upgrade the actual potency of your drink, that hasn't been made any easier to compensate.  The previous point is worsened by the fact that all character animations have been drastically slowed down. Did you love Dark Souls because of how smooth and fluid it's movements and controls were? Then do not buy this game. I swear my character was walking through some kind of syrup. This is somewhat lessened by adding points into the Adaptability stat (Read as, you must waste souls to level and extra stat in order to use your estus flask without moving in slow motion) but even after that the animations and recovery periods from any action are still slow.  I mentioned an Adapability stat. This is not the only new stat that has been added which is nothing more than a piece of a previously present stat. Remember how nice it was that you could boost equipload and stamina at the same time? Not anymore, that has now been split into 2 stats just to force you to spend more souls in leveling. The splitting of stats has actually even forced the pvp meta up 50 or so levels. Hope you like grinding through enemies that stop respawning.  In all, Dark Souls 2 abandons things which made Dark Souls 1 great, trades fair and fun challenges for annoying and cheap ones, messes with mechanics that did not need to be chagned only to leave them worse than they started, and is overall a disappointment after playing through the masterpiece which was Dark Souls 1. Your money is much better spent on the first game, at this point I am certain that I can guarantee you will have more fun with it.

First of all, I have been playing all Souls games to get a feel for them individually. Dark Souls 2 seems to be the ugly cow in the farm mostly do to the fact that the original game director was busy with Bloodborne. Well, I must say that is not an issue and the team responsible for making this game did a great job. In the presentation department, the world seems fuller. Also, there are more npcs this time around that breath life into the world. Story, while still vague, is presented in better fashion than the previous game and as you explore along, some areas really depict a believable history in the World of Drangleic. Giants, fallen kings, betryal, war, humanity. The world has rich lore and it's sold pretty well, if you look for it.     Combat feels smooth, new animations look good and are varied. It's a bit slower though and character feels heavier when performing certain animations which I don't prefer but it's not a big issue. Had problems with the lock-on not locking on when I wanted to nor changing targets which is annoying but it can be managed.    The biggest downside for me is in the boss battles. There are more this time around but they have been stripped down and eased up from previous game. Most of the bossess designs seem unespired and only a few stood out. It does not compare to the Original game where every boss was memorable. While some would be easy but they where still impactfull. Here, not so much.    On a lighter note, I have to give MAYOR props for the guys who optimized and configured this game. Game runs really smooth and in the highest settings. The original Dark Souls suffered from mayor frame rate drops and I experienced the same in Dark Souls 3 even on lowest settings. Goes to show that the team behind this game, did a great job without the direction of 'THE BIG MAN.'   To conclude, the game is great regardless of some minor let downs. Pvp is an improvement. A number of areas where desgined as battle arenas for online play and serve as interesting playgrounds. Some areas are challenging to traverse like Iron Keep and the game changes tone as the game goes on. The world may not be the masterful design the Original was but, it's still a world worth exploring with some amazing set pieces. Also. all three chunks of dlc are superb and challenging. Great stuff here.

It's a decent, robust dungeon crawler with lots of equipment, spells, 4 schools of magic, and lots of content, but I can't help but feel disappointed by it, because it simply can't live up to the wonderful experience that was Dark Souls I, thanks to its poor, often overly linear level design, poorly thought-out world (both in terms of level placement, and the lore of the world), and idiotic, polarising mechanics changes that happened for no reason.  In terms of how it stacks up against the original Dark Souls II, it's slightly better. Scholar of The First Sin, however, has been criticised too much for the shady business practices behind it, and too unfairly lauded much more than it deserved, when it came to its design changes; and people ignore glaring design flaws that would be criticised to no end in other games. For example, the Pursuer, an early boss in the game, is supposed to pursue the undead, so Scholar of the First Sin opts to place him all about the world. An interesting idea, yeah, but every single Pursuer encounter has the exact same moveset, exact same weapon, and exact same basic arena (that being a large circular or rectangular plane). Other changes, too, like the Heide Knights (an obviously unfair enemy; being able to break out of your combos and instantly lash out for huge damage, encouraging the player to game the system with ranged tactics) appearing in Heide, or the Fragrant Branch of Yore system being much more heavily engrained result in some even more utterly unforgiveable situations; it is literally possible to get stuck in the Lost Bastille, and forced to kill yourself, if you use a certain Fragrant Branch. Needless to say, the level design may visit some interesting locales and vistas, but the actual layout of the levels themselves, and the movement engine, too, is on-par with amateur projects in Unity, even if it is a slight improvement over vanilla DS2.   Speaking of amateur projects, Dark Souls II's enemies and bosses are also utterly uninspired and game-y. The Old Iron King is a giant, Diablo-like torso, which you fight in a wasteland of lava, and it shoots fire lasers out of its hand. Dark Souls even tackled a similar concept with one of its bosses, but it was executed far better, given a genuinely tragic and sad backstory, and some interesting behaviours, and strangely enough, the Old Iron King is just as bad, gameplay-wise, as its Dark Souls I counterpart. There are also plenty of polarising mechanical changes. Combat in Dark Souls II may seem faster to inexperienced players, but in reality, pretty much every player action in combat has been artificially slowed down; you now chug estus at a leisurely, insanely slow rate, regenerate stamina at a 'I've never done cardio in my life' rate, and many movesets have been changed to be slower. Dark Souls II is poorly designed, however, and paradoxically, the enemies still seem to be designed for Dark Souls I; the Drakekeepers in a later area have nearly infinite stamina; the Lost Sinner has nearly infinite stamina, very little recovery time, and the ability to exploit low invincibility frames if the lights are turned off, and many enemies like the Manikins resort to running up to the player and flailing wildly, and these enemies are often placed in groups. All of this enemy placement just feels restrictive and cheap, whereas previous games never heavily encouraged the player to use spells, or ranged weapons, Dark Souls II seems to be constantly rewarding players who do this, while extending a middle finger to those who don't by throwing cheap, objectively unfair things at players, like invaders, i.e human NPC enemies, that have stats too ridiculous for any human player to ever get.  My biggest problem with DS2, and SoTFS, though, is that it has no soul. Dark Souls and Demon's Souls respectively were great experiences which will stay with me for years to come; and their atmospheres, worlds, and challenges all cultivated games which really resonated with a lot of people, but most indicting thing I can say about DS2, is that it's 'just another game'.  The truth is that Dark Souls II: Scholar of the First Sin is a fairly good dungeon crawler, which ironically has many fewer design flaws than your average, run-of-the-mill modern games, and one with lots of areas, and countless weapons, spells and armour sets to experiment with, and there's a lot to see, and there are some stand-out bosses and areas; and the DLC areas in particular have some spectacular bosses (and two utterly ♥♥♥♥♥ bosses), and there is certainly lots of great design work to see in Dark Souls II, but there's too much to hinder the enjoyment of most people who really appreciated Dark Souls I.  Personally, I recommend that you start with another game in the series, or that, if you've just completed Dark Souls I, you go back and play Demon's Souls; a game which is well-designed, fair, and pays attention to more important details and atmosphere.

Absolutely fantastic!   - Dark Souls 2 is easily among the best RPG games I have ever played.  After quite some time with this game I have come to give this review some more depth. The first section of this review will be for people that have never played a 'From Software' game before and the other section will focus on the controversy surrounding this remastered version  It`s difficult but when you start to come around at the fourth boss or so and get the hang of it`s gameplay mechanics, Dark Souls 2 will drag you into the world and keep you immersed for months. The world is rich with story and detail. The difficulty is always fair and when you finally take down that difficult enemy you have been analyzing for hours you get that satisfaction only DS can give you. From an RPG standpoint the leveling , gear, weapons, dialoug...basically everything is done with such class and confidence that it will be hard to find anything flawed. I know I sound like a fanboy but when a game comes around and gives me a whole new perspective of how I play and enjoy video games. you know it`s something special.  Even if you`re scared of the difficulty I promise you it will be worth it, if you give it time. I too was hesitant about playing Dark Souls in general but oh my how glad I am I did.  Now for the package itself. I do think it`s in general a bad idea to release a remaster in the timespan of less than 2 years. It`s a cash-in, although it was primarily made for the PS4/Xbox One users who got a terrible last gen version of this game. They will certainly experience a much bigger difference in both graphics and performance.   On the PC, the graphical upgrade is nice but DS2 already looked good to begin with. Only noticable change I can see at the moment is the lighting which has improved and actually gives the torch some purpose. With that said. DO NOT buy this remaster for the graphics alone. Not worth it!  Another controversial topic has been the splitting of the community and I do agree that it was a pretty ♥♥♥♥ move on Namco`s behalf. This needs to stop. On console it`s fine but on PC it`s different. There are no performance differences between the versions which makes the server split pointless. Well, a huge amount of time has passed since I tried Dark Souls 2 for the first time, but I want to review this game because I'm playing again in these days. Isn't it?  Well...to be honest this probably is not entirely true: I found DS2 to be the easiest Dark Souls I have ever played. There are only 3 good boss fights, while all the other are trivial. Few traps. Few danger.   What about the level design?  In the first chapter all the areas were logically connected and there were a nice amount of shortcuts to bring you faster to the main hub. In Dark Souls 2 you have a teleport function that let you jump from bonefire to bonefire. This is wonderful, right? Wrong! Thanks to this now all the areas are randomly connected thanks to corridors/elevator, with no shortcuts and without that feeling of cohesion.  And all those wonderful characters? All gone. Only 3 characters are really well made, with a nice storyline and a nice quest (Pate for Quest and story, Lucatiel for story...well, can't find a third character right now ^^').  Most of Souls player says that this Dark Souls is the worst for this problems and other more, but I must disagree with them. This game has good things too, like a better gameplay. There are plenty of weapons, when on the first chapter only 2 weapons were actually useful. Your character's response from your input is really nice, with no random rolling or getting stuck on an invisible wall while rolling.   For this reason I do recommend this game. In my opinion those downsides are little things you have to bear to have a smoother gameplay.
It's not got the great storyline and level design the first game had, but the gameplay feels more polished. Fair tradeoff, I guess.

This game is probably the most disliked in the series by fans of the souls series, and I have to agree with many of the points raised by people who dislike this game. However, this is far from a bad game, but the first Dark Souls set such a high standard that it would have been extremely difficult to please everyone. But the game definitely still needs to be played, it has some really memorable moments and boss fights, and if you're into PvP it was definitely improved from the first game.  But I have to agree with a lot of fans when they say that there's definitely 'something' that's just missing from the sequel.  The world of Dark Souls 1 was just incredible, one of the best designed worlds in gaming, I can still go back and play the game now and still love the world, the atmosphere, the amazing design, I've replayed it so many times. The entire world of the 1st game felt connected, there were shortcuts and secrets littered throughout, however DS2 goes in a different direction. Instead of having the world feel 'connected', you will be warping from bonfire to bonfire a lot, which really takes something away from what made the first game great, and made the world feel natural and beautifully designed.  I remember finishing DS2 for the first time and having absolutely no desire to play it again, the only reason I'm playing it through again now is because of the DLC which I never got on console. I replayed the first game several times on console without any of the DLC, and played through it twice again when I got the Prepare to Die edition on PC. It was just an amazing experience that felt naturally challenging.  On the subject of challenge, Dark Souls 2 is definitely difficult, but it just feels 'forced' and very lazy at times, not to mention extremely cheap, and not in the fun 'lol dark souls' way, I mean the '♥♥♥♥ the lazy devs who made this dumb boss/mob enemy section' kind of way.  The first game actually never really made me frustrated, because the difficulty felt so natural, I knew I was doing something wrong. (Except for that ♥♥♥♥ing giant dragon bodies in bright orange lava section in Lost Izalith, which even the developers admitted was rushed and a mistake.)  DS2 has many areas where the developers just seem to get extremely lazy and throw in mobs of enemies, it doesn't feel challenging, it just feels frustrating and extremely cheap when you get swarmed by 5 or 6 large enemies in one area, it's a real motivation killer for continuing the game, particularly for a returning player who really just wants to play for the DLC. There's a difference between well designed challenge, and just throwing a ♥♥♥♥ load of enemies in a small room or choke point, and telling the players to deal with the developers laziness 'because dark souls'.  That's probably my biggest personal gripe with this game, the laziness of a few of the more frustrating sections.  But even with it's flaws, it's still a great ♥♥♥♥ing game, that I would recommend you should play at least once. Great combat and atmosphere, and when the difficulty is done well, it has that feeling of accomplishment when you do finally kill a boss, or get past that one area that keeps messing you up.  In my opinion, you shouldn't go into the game expecting it to be as good or even better than the first, because I don't think it is. But this game is really great in it's own right, and deserves to be played at least once.

Scholar of the First Sin was announced immediately after the final expansion was released and I like many others was pretty irritated about. I purchased it recently on PC due to the sale although I also have the PS4 version as well. Having ignored it for nearly six months I feel I can look at this a little more objectively.  Whether this update is worth purchasing really depends on how much you enjoyed the vanilla version. Enemy placements have been tweaked, NPC summon signs and invasions are much more prominent and a few creative elements have been added in certain places (some of which are admittedly pretty interesting). There is also a ring in the game that allows you to control Soul Memory to a certain degree, although this is a band aid solution and doesn't really fix the core problem. Lighting seems to be improved and makes torches less optional in a couple of places but if you are looking for E3 levels of fidelity then you should probably keep moving. Lastly, a character very important to the lore makes multiple appearances. Speaking of lore, item descriptions have also been given the once over.   All in all, the game feels very familiar but also quite different. All the above mentioned tweaks and alterations to progression paths (you'll be using more Fragrant Branches of Yore than usual) make this update feel akin to a Director's Cut or Extended Edition bluray with all the added extras from the previous iterations. If you loved the regular game and don't mind starting from scratch (saves don't carry over) then it could be worth it. However the vanilla game has been updated via patch to include most of the features that aren't related to performance so it really does depend on how much you want the extra player count, slightly better lighting and enemy placement re-shuffle. If you weren't much of a fan to begin with then nothing here is going to change that.  So, should you buy it?   Newcomers... Definitely. Longtime Players... Yes, if you want to spice things up a little. But Not essential. Casual Players... Don't bother, you probably won't appreciate or care about any of the changes.

While I think that Dark Souls 1 in many ways exceeded Demon's Souls, Dark Souls II ultimately feels like a step backward.   The Graphics are Better, and there isn't any 'Dump' stat (Luck aor Resiliance) like the previous two souls games, but the game overall feels a little watered down from the tight design of its predecessors. The possible exception to this is the comparitively remarkable DLC, but said DLC is unfortunately locked inside a game where you absolutely must bring in a powered up - or underpowered - character to play them, destroying the developer's ability to properly pace the challenges the same way as if the levels were integrated into the main game.  There are several ways the level design falls short, and I think a deeper analysis would be appropriate, but for the sake of this short Steam Review I'll touch upon the two most glaring issues.   The first Level Design issue is that there are just too many areas where the layout is completely linear. The biggest sins are in the late game, such as where you literally run accross a narrow stretch of land in the middle of a lake flanked by sorcerous snipers, or when you enter a mansion that ends up just being a long hallway with optional doors on either side. There are GOOD levels, like the No-Man's Wharf (as short as it is) and the Depths, but in the previous games I think I could name only ONE area from each that could use a little more imaginative polish. With Dark Souls II it's more than half the game.   Incidentally, this lack of imagination also applies to the bosses. While some bosses like the Last Giant might have a story to tell, a lot of boss rooms with health bars are just glorified mini-bosses. I think giving them the 'boss' treatment drained a bit from the epicness of the title - and the simple design choice of just making them like the Vanguard Demon in Demon's Souls would have made the better bosses stand out a little more. Between the (mechanical) level design and these kinds of 'bosses', it makes Dark Souls II feel like it's stuffed with poor filler content.   Adding to this issue is the Second Level Design issue I want to bring up, and that's the thematic problem. Dark Souls 1 had a fluid and cohesive world to explore, where you could write a story just by the way things are connected. The first great obstacle you have to face is an enomous wall that would be daunting to scale even if that was an option in the game. The ONLY way you can get through it is by proving your worth and ringing the bells of awakening. Dark Souls 2 - the obstacle is a barely eye-level collapsed pillar, and you overcome it by going through a locked gazebo that opens based on how many souls you collected, and MAYBE based on killing 4 unrelated bosses. (If you don't believe me about the pillar thing, check it out for yourself.)  In Dark Souls 1, when you go to the 'lava level' you have to do so through Blight Town, then defeat a powerful pyromancer spider queen, and THEN you find yourself deep in the depths of the earth where the demons roam. In Dark Souls II, for some reason going up an elevator that's already in a tower IN THE SKY, for some reason this leads to a place surrounded by Lava. Could it be a floating continent? Well, that'd be cool, but no, because the whole story behind this place is that the King built a castle out of Iron and it's sinking into the earth... But based on how you get there, it has to be in the SKY! These are the kind of things that you might not have noticed... but your brain did. Personally I think the thematic level design also has a lot to do with the way this game just doesn't feel the same as the other two souls games.   But the DLC levels are GREAT. I wish they were the whole game, and I really think they're the reason I'm tipping this review to 'Recommend' instead of just giving it the thumbs down.   I haven't played Bloodborne or Dark Souls 3 yet so I can't make any comparisons there, but I still think I can safely say that Dark Souls 2 is a skippable entry. It isn't BAD by any means, it's just not the kind of quality that we should be demanding from From Software. If you buy this, make sure you play the DLC - though I couldn't blame you if you find yourself feeling a little burnt out by the game's main content - even with its few moments of brilliance.   Honestly though, if Dark Souls sequels are just going to be like what we got for the base Dark Souls II, then I really don't want any more Souls games.  3 out of 5

Now that I've finished this PC version of this game as well (had played it on the console before) I thought I'd write a review with what I like/dislike about this version/the game in general.  The SotFS edition adds some DLC areas/bosses as well as changing a few existing locations/monsters. Instead of finding some rather easy water trolls in the area before a certain bossfight, instead you'll find a smaller version of the 2-bodied flexile sentry down there which, if you don't expect it, makes for a small 'help' moment. I wouldn't say it made the game harder (like some reviews claim) but just a bit different. While on that topic, I still don't think Dark Souls 2 (or SotFS) is a difficult game. The bosses rarely use tactics that can't be dodged (which you'll learn right from the start to do properly, more so by normal enemies than bosses) and you'll become a dodge master before you've even finished the game. Sure, some bossfights take quite some time when playing with a different class (I've had more trouble with some of the earlier enemies than bosses or later game normal enemies) but overal it's not a 'hard' game. Difficulty doesn't come from giving enemies more health/let them do more damage, that just makes fights take longer. And once you get the hang of it, you'll learn to only take 2 swipes at a boss and roll away after the second hit instead of being cheeky and try to get a third off as well. Patience is the key with any fight.  So, if it's not an incredibly difficult game, why do you hear so many people (including me) become rather upset about it? For pretty obviosu reasons; it's a poor console port. Sure, you don't need to install mods (and risk getting banned from online play) in order to play on 60FPS, which is a blessing, but they haven't thought about a lot of useful things.  For starters, the key mapping. Yes, I've played this game from beginning to ending with a keyboard and mouse. Yes, I do own a controller and yes, I do know that makes some things easier, like pickign between a power attack and a normal attack (which when using a mouse means double clicking, which ofcourse doesn't work 99% of the time but instead you swipe a normal attack twice). That's more of an annoyance, but furthermore, a lot of keybinds cant be properly relocated to the keys you want meaning you'll have to use either your movement hand towards the arrow keys or you're aiming/attack hand in order to change spells/items, leaving you vulnerable to incoming attacks, which is critical duing PvP fights. Most of the changes to this version of the game merely involve changing item placement and enemy locations. It doesn't solve any of the big issues that were massive turn offs of Dark Souls 2. Rather than trying to make areas more interesting, the developers simply added more enemies to make it 'challenging'. What you get instead is a fodder grind that drains your resources and time that simply makes large portions of the game tedious.   Most of the bosses remain boring, and borrow from the same mechanics or strategies as others. You simply need to block or avoid most attacks and you're rewarded with a single swing. This just adds to the mounting frustration. In previous Souls titles, you could weather attacks or create openings for yourself, but no such opportunities exist here. Many of the bosses you will encounter are either a generic humanoid enemy, or multiple bosses, often both. A lot of them don't fit the area they're in very well, which adds to the cluster that is the lore. Not to mention the massive hitbox issues that persist.  Online functionality is laughable at best. Hackers and packet filter users are everywhere and you'll often get invaded or invade someone with a decent connection at first but will suddenly be facing an enemy who teleports around and back stabs you from nowhere. The game is best played pretending these features currently don't exist. It's a shame too, because when the PvP match isn't against one of these people, they're probably the best part of the game.  In terms of mechanics, FROM has implemented many changes, most of which make little sense. They made all defenses weaker by drastically lowering stamina recovery while blocking to nearly nothing, and making base rolls worse. You now need to invest in a new stat, Agility, to bring the invincibility of rolling back to something worth while. Endurance from the previous game is now split into two stats. While this may balance the stat against others, when combined with Agility results in a large drain of level ups that feel pretty meaningless. In addition, weapon requirements and scaling feel very inconsistent, some of which don't make much sense. The high base damage of enemies combined with stats not increasing resistances makes armor simalarly feel worthless. It's a hodge podge of conflicted design, the game wants you to not sit back and defend all day but the bosses will only ever allow a single safe swing before harshly punishing you for the greed of a second.  Graphically, it's gorgeous. This version of the game runs very steadily which is a definite plus. Something to consider though, for some reason Lock Guard appears to be enabled by default. You'll need to bind a key to remove this.  It should surprise no one who played the previous games that the development team for this title was different. It shows in their complete lack of understanding of what made the series great. What we've got instead is a passable game instead of a brilliant one. Perhaps a good buy at $20 or less, but is not worth the current price tag.

I think I can safely say, if you're skeptical about the game, it's worth the money if you feel like re-experiencing Dark Souls II. If you've been eye-balling this game I'd recommend that you pick it up. It's not in your standard faire of ARPGs. This game does not hold your hand and it's a challenge for the sake of the challenge, and I love it.  Combat is almost puzzle-like. You need to learn and understand what each of your moves do and how to best use them. Then you need to learn what your opponets move set is and how to counter, parry, backstab, block, and generally move through their attacks.   This game is difficult in the sense that their is so many skills to master and so much to take in. Nothing is automated so you could potentially play through most of the game before you realize that different types of shields have differing movesets, etc. You could also go multiple playthroughs without fully understanding how your equipment load effects your stamina, rolls, run speed, etc etc. This game encourages trial and error. Whether that means falling off cliffs to see if you can get to a secret area, walking along stretches of wall and tapping your action key looking for secret passages, to figuring out whether poison works on what bosses. There will never be a popup saying go to this area next. It's all on you. Each time you die you also lose all your souls, which is a combination of currency and XP, with a single chance to go back and reclaim it or it'll be lost for good. You'll probably backtrack a lot trying to figure out what's next. The story isn't spoonfed to you. It's found through talking through each NPC's dialog, reading equipment descriptions, and observing the environment & your enemies. If you kill the enemies enough, they respawn everytime you rest to regain health etc, they will eventually stop respwning potentially making an area easier. This allows you to farm for souls and equipment.  There is also a metagame referred to as 'fashion souls' among DS players. There is so much gear and equipment to collect, and potentially upgrade, that you can darn well look like whatever you like, using whatever weapons you like. Cosplaying is common.  Then you get PvP/CoOp. Co-op is done through leaving summoning signs or joining covenants that summon you to other players worlds (to aid them against PvP'ers). Co-op is helpful for getting through an area or challenging a boss. PvP is done with summoning signs, joining covenants that summon other people to your world or you to theirs (territory defense style), it's also done with items that allow you invade someone else's world. PvP/Co-op is useful for advancing levels in covenants which provide gear/spells, but it's also bring new dimensions to this game after you put in dozens of hours messing around PvE.  The Souls game all have a New Game+ mechanic. After you beat the game you can restart it with your gear, but everything is more powerful and difficult. DS2 has a mechanic that allows you to NG+ and area after beat a boss. There's a cap on how high it can go (I've never reached it but I've never tried to either), but I've seen people on their Original NG and having one or two areas NG+8. A quick warning, if you NG an area and then beat the game and NG the whole game, that area that has already been NG+ will roll over to the next difficulty (e.g. NG+ overall, but that one NG+3 will roll over to NG+4). Each NG+ will introduce new equipment and enemies (and more enemies).   There are still bugs in this game, and each time Fromsoft releases content they just add more bugs, much to the hackers delight. You can be invaded by people that hack anything from invincibility to superpowers to even having different skins. This causes some major frustration, especially for me. I don't enjoy people raiding me constantly that are doing it knowing I have no way to combat them. Lag can also be a huge problem (shut off that streaming radio), I'd recommend keeping yourself region locked unless you have a fast connection and an awesome ping rate. While Dark Souls 2 treads on familiar and beautiful ground in the Souls series, it trips along the way. To start off, Dark Souls 2 can be a bit too unforgiving, even for a Souls game. When the player dies, their maximum health is cut by a small amount, shrinking with every subsequent death after. It punishes the player too much for making mistakes, forcing them to scrounge around for Human Effigies in order to regain their maximum health.  Parries and riposte is more difficult to pull off in 2, giving a longer wind up time to the parry, and not allowing the player to immediately riposte. The whole system is so bad, I tried to avoid it as much as I could for most of my time through the game.  Now despite these faults, Dark Souls 2's gameplay is still farily fun, and still possesses some challenge, albiet not as much as the first, but enough to merit some fun. The game is even more gorgeous and impressive art wise than its predecessor, possessing more nightmarish enemies than ever before, and incredible locales. While the areas are more linear than before, I couldn't help but stop multiple times to appreciate the amazing detail that went into the areas.  Overall, Dark Souls 2 is good. Not great, not amazing, and no where near as good as 1. It's just not as difficult, and possesses wasted mechanics such as the parry and riposte.  8/10

I'm basing this review on having never played the DX9 PC version. Previously, I'd played through the game on the Xbox360. At that time, I was a little sad for DkS2; I thought it was good, but compared to DkS1 kinda, well, boring. So, I was kinda a bit unsure on whether I should pick this up now I've dropped the Xbox for PC.  First impressions, it's better. Ignoring the graphic upgrade for the moment, which is what I'd expect from a PC game in the first place, I've already had more fun playing this version in two hours than I had in playing the origional version in, god, 80 or something. It's mostly little things, like the enemy AI seems better, the small changes to placement, the fact that, yes, there are some gank squads out there, but so far I've yet to run into one that feels unfair. There are some nice little environmental changes (additional gunpowder barrels, i'm looking at you) that you can use to your advantage. It just feels, in terms of gameplay, more what I'd expect from a Souls game.  The game runs fine, as well (better than DkS1, which, you know, is hilarious) and is nice and smooth right out of the box, although I notcied some graphical and audio stutter in the opening cutscene. Nothing horrendous, but it was eyebrow raising.  So, the graphics...... I'm sure that the DX9 version is just as good with mods, but this looks fine out of the box. The lighting still isn't as lush as that promised by the infamous E3 demo, but there are now areas that are pitch black. It's funny, but I never thought I'd be happy to not be able to see what I'm doing. I'm looking forward to seeing how the gutter plays now (something else I'd never thought i'd say).  As for the durability bug, yep, that's ~very~ obvious. Oddly, though, I don't mind it. Even weider, I actually prefer it. Having to consider the weapons you have and making sure you keep backups adds a nice, if unintended, twist in play.  Overall handling, the game feels slightly harder, slightly weightier (compared to the floaty experience i had on the 360, anyway), but also oddly fairer. Even though I played it death last year, it now feels more fun, more interesting and pleasantly fresh.  In short, I'd like to totally echo what everybody else has been saying. This is how the game should have been released in the first place (hell, the lush lighting in E3 version should have been the aim for the PC), and if you've got the DX9 version with all the mods and DLC then you've really got to ask yourself if it's worth it. However, if, like me, you've only played it on last gen consoles, or you've never played it full stop, or you bought it in the xmas sale and haven't picked up the DLC yet, then have no qualms about picking it up.  Although, do yourself a favour, and drop brightness in game down to 0.  9/10 - would die before creating character again.

Before I begin, I would like to join the chorus: COULD THE ESTUS DRINKING TIME BE ANY SLOWER? Seriously...  I should preface by saying that I have played and beaten the original Dark Souls and its DLC. I thoroughly enjoyed that title but this go around felt very different. The hours spent on the two weren't terribly different, but this game felt twice as long and half as enjoyable. Don't get me wrong. I wouldn't say that Dark Souls 2 is a BAD game, it just doesn't live up to the glory of the original and suffers from some poor design choices that really make parts of the game a chore. I think those who played the original will still get something out of the sequel, but those first entering the Dark Souls universe would be better served starting at the beginning of the series. Fighting mechanics have been improved (spare the awful hit-boxes) but new players won't be missing out on anything by passing on this one. Dark Souls 2 suffers a variety of flaws that alone would be tolerable but put together make the game fairly boring and sometimes downright miserable.  My biggest technical problem was the extraordinary lack of human effigies in the game. I never understood the purpose of humanity in the original title and so never used effigies. After learning that one could summon assistance with bosses by using them I was pleasantly surprised by how much more fun the game could be with a little help. Being hollowed-out also came with a health penalty that could be really detrimental at times. So with my new-found knowledge of effigies I began to use them often only finding out later how rare they were. The rarity of effigy drops didn't bother me at first because I figured vendors would surely sell them along the way. Problem was: vendors only sell so many before they are sold out for good. Just farm them from enemies that drop them in the field, right? That would work, except that after killing a particular enemy a certain number of times the game stops spawning it forever. You can work around this with bonfire ascetics but the increased difficulty of the area is a cost that far outweighs the benefits. The fact of the matter is that the health penalty of being hollow is far too great in this game and only serves to frustrate the player. The game is already hard enough. The developers should have made buying effigies a persistent option and just made them really expensive.  The lack of interesting environments and atmosphere was also a perpetual drag on the game. The original Dark Souls had a number of places that were really beautiful and awe-inspiring and the areas had a nice sense of scope, size, and cohesion that made sense. Dark Souls 2 is a patchwork of locations that are mostly uninteresting and offer little to no reason for return. There are no vendors, side-quests, or NPCs that make returning beneficial, so most are drive-through areas that clearly did not receive any thoughtful consideration from the devs. Some area transitions, like the one from the final elevator of Earthen Peak to the entrance of the Iron Keep, were just plain bizarre. Exploration of the world and the slaying of optional bosses doesn't yield much reward to the player either which is particularly disappointing after being brutalized by an area like the Frigid Outskirts. Touching on this point, the lack of NPCs in this game made it feel all the more hollow. Part of the charm of Dark Souls was its characters like Sir Onion and Trusty Patches who really rounded-out the game and gave it that dash of humor that was sometimes desperately needed. Their voice-acting and scripts were really fun and memorable. Dark Souls 2 is completely devoid of any interesting NPCs, save the Emerald Herald, who the protagonist rarely has any meaningful interactions with. My one hope in the game was to at least see some grand development of the Emerald Herald's story, some big animated ending that included some resolution for her. But 'Alas, nothing happened': we have about 3 short dialogs with her through the course of the game with no mention of her in the end. Epic. Disappointment.  With no unique plot developments or interesting NPCs the game comes off as just a poor carbon-copy of the original game and this doesn't just apply to the story. While some of the bosses you fight along your journey are fresh many are just cut-and-paste from the original Dark Souls. The Belfry Luna gargoyles are literally bosses right out of the original game. And although both are optional the game includes two nearly-identical fights with the Smelter Demon boss. The bosses of the Iron King and the Ivory King DLCs are true to the original vision but the base game bosses are weak and unmemorable for the most part. The battle with the Ivory King, which involves the ability to hire four knights and summon two spirits to assist in a group battle with the boss, was truly epic in contrast. I really wish we were given more refreshing battles like that. More group-oriented activities would have been much-appreciated and offered the players something truly different. On the boss side of things, I will give the devs some credit: The battle with the Fume Knight was exceptionally hard and the duel with Sir Alonne nearly made my chest explode. Good work.  But what was most damning for me was the general lack of direction in the game. This was tolerable in the original Dark Souls because it was a much smaller and cohesive world; if you poked around enough you would find where you were supposed to go. The world of Dark Souls 2 is much larger in scope by comparison and the DLC worlds make it even broader. I myself spent several hours in the Brume Tower after finishing off the Fume Knight having NO idea where to go to next. I couldn't find the last smelter wedge to kill the last Ashen Idol and knew it had to be somewhere in the Brume Tower. Turns out: I was wrong. After a few hours of wandering I finally resorted to consulting the internet for direction. If a seasoned video game player is doing this in your game you know you've failed royally. There is no indication that there is nothing to do in the DLC areas when you finish off their bosses and the fact that finishing them does not affect the story or gameplay is quite a disappointment.   On top of all of this the DLC areas are locked behind doors strewn about the world. Yes, they are locked. Where are the keys, you ask? They are hidden in random places in the world as well. The dragon talon required to open the Crown of the Sunken King is hidden behind a door that itself is locked by yet ANOTHER key hidden in ANOTHER hidden area. What the ♥♥♥♥ is that about? Why on Earth would you hide access to these areas and offer no leads to finding their keys?  I would love to go on about the empty story that I just stopped trying to understand about half-way through the game, but the small amounts of muddled history and plot leave hardly anything to comment upon. The 'story' is a tedious, poorly-developed afterthought. Enough said.  When I first finished this game a few days ago I didn't realize how much I didn't like it, but after writing this review I came to realize how many key areas this game fell short on. The empty ending cinematic felt like a real slap in the face after having sunk so many hellish hours into this game. I feel like I've put more effort into this game than the developers did. I can't recommend this game to new players of the series. Stick to playing the original for now. I haven't played Dark Souls 3 yet, and I've heard it's better, but this game has left me wary of trying it.  Oh, and whoever designed the Frigid Outskirts: I hope you get hit by a bus...

With each leap to an important moment in Johnny's memories, they learn more about him and what brought him to his current position in life, including his largely unhappy marriage to his childhood sweetheart, River. Upon reaching his childhood, the doctors attempt to insert his desire to go to the moon. Supposedly, Johnny's mind would create new memories based on that desire, and Johnny would die believing he lived without any regrets. I just finished Dark Souls [1], and moved on to the second game and... no. This is not fun. This is frustrating for all the wrong reasons. The level design is ALREADY annoying me, it feels even more clunky than DS1 (which I played without the fix that makes it run better), and although the graphics are gorgeous compared to DS1, I'm just not interested in playing this game. Yes, in DS1 I had a rough beginning, but I pushed on because I at least felt like, for the first few hours, I could make some progress. After a while, I got into my groove and I loved it. I played it twice before I felt like I wanted to move on to Dark Souls II, which I had bought in the same sale. But after only a few hours, and relatively little progress, even less understanding of what's going on and much less interesting level design (and I'm only talking about the first area you play, the most important part of the game for interesting a new player), I just cannot like this game enough to recommend it or even continue to play it.  My main problem is this: I'm BORED. It's not that I'm bored of dying. I don't mind dying. I played through DS1 and DS1 NG+, remember, I can handle the rage at dying. But I'm bored of mechanics that make it deliberately more frustrating from the getgo (e.g. only one estus flask at the beginning, which is totally useless, permanently losing a chunk of my health when I die unless I use a rare item which I only have 1 of so far, ridiculously low stats that improve so slowly with levelling that I'm worried that I might actually not be able to go down any other path than stamina because rolling literally uses half my bar at a time and enemies do more damage than I can block). I'm bored because I have no idea WHY I'm doing anything (the beginning of the game is less than impressive, to be honest, and does nothing to give me a drive to play it). I'm bored because, unlike in DS1 where you can be methodical and make your way through a level multiple times if you're really careful and you learn where the enemies are, this game is just one massive ambush after another, with ranged enemies you can't even stop attacking you, while you're trying to fight melee monsters who can one hit you, and you rely on luck rather than skill to make it through an encounter and get to the next one that you haven't yet been lucky enough to pass (and you can't even heal before you go into because you have literally no way of doing so since your 2 estus flasks are long gone). I'm bored because the level design is, honestly, just awful. Linear and then not linear, a hundred different routes which are all just BLOCKED OFF by locked doors, horrible enemies guarding dead ends with rubbish loot, archers in every concievable spot, one ambush after another that are designed to get you killed rather than you being able to carefully engage each enemy at a time and avoid certain death (after all, you have to go through the same area a large number of times, it isn't fun if you only make it past the first ambush once every 10 attempts because it's basically just luck if you survive), I can go on, and on, as the empty distances you have to run between areas go on, and on...  In short, I just can't be f***ed. Dying is too punishing for a game where you basically just die for a living (in a manner of speaking). The level design is too boring and annoying for me to want to struggle through even the first area. The fights feel too unfair and the mechanics are too clunky for me to be bothered to deal with them. And the drive to play it, the excitement I had in the first game, the interesting concept and inclination to progress (as well as the ability to progress) just isn't there. My biggest complaint, at the end of the day, is that DS2 has just failed to interest me. I would much rather go back and play some more DS1, and will.   I might come back to this game, I might even end up liking it 10 hours down the road when I have decent gear and reasonable stats, but right now, while it's on sale, I want to say this: buy DS1, it's cheaper and it's better, but don't do what I did and buy BOTH while they're on sale expecting to like both. Only buy this game if you liked DS1 and are willing to put up with new and odd design choices and even more awkward mechanics (as if DS1 isn't frustrating enough) from the start. I, personally, cannot, at current, be bothered.   P.S. I've been playing DS2 for 3 hours at the time of review and I am yet to fight a single boss. This bothers me deeply. In fairness, I spent half an hour staring at the gorgeous views in the main town at the beginning before I was willing to actually start the game, but in DS1 you stumble onto a boss's head in about ten minutes and subsequently get flattened. That's a real Souls game.

An unbelivably rewarding game for those with the patience to learn its systems.  Dark Souls II is an amazing game and a great sequel. Taking place in the same world as Dark Souls but in another land and another time, you once again find your self a cursed undead in a hostle land full of undead, demons, monsters and giants. and you Defeate the mightest souls of the land to become the next Monarch. But first you must die. and die and die and die again.  Dark Souls II is very similar mechanically and graphically to Dark Souls but the combat has been given a tune up and feels smoother, more fluid. Dark Souls II also changes up a few gameplay details. The biggest being that enemies won't respawn forvever. after you've killed enemies in an area about 10 times, they will stop respawning. This forces you to explore ever further into the game and fight harder and harder foes. It also means that if you die and fail to recover your souls thats less souls left in the game that you could have used to level up or buy things so every soul counts. That being said there are tons of enemies in this game so its very unlikely you'll screw up so bad you won't be able to progress.  While i love most of the changes to Dark Souls II i am a little dissapointed in the lack of boss creatvity in this one. Bosses are the staple in the Souls games (and blood bourne) but in Souls II most of the bosses are some varient of big dude in a suit of armor. Thats not to say fighting them isn't fun, i just wish there was more bosses like the giant fire demon in Demons Souls or The Four Kings in Dark Souls. This seems to be a best of bosses collection with several bosses that feel like re-skins of Dark Souls bosses. They even put the bell gargoyle boss fight in this game unchanged in any way.  But this is a small nitpick and there are still a few stand out boss fights in this one.   When all is said i think i like this game better than the original Dark Souls. I think the changes to the game mechanics make the game more fun and since enemies only respawn a limited number of times it means even if an area is kicking your ♥♥♥ you can gradually empty it one enemy at a time. This is one of the best games i've played in years. Like in the first game, if you have the patience and can except death is a learning experince in this game then you'll have a lot of fun with this game.   Oh and if you've already played the Dark Souls II, this new version makes major changes to the whole game. not just adding new content but also re arranging the enemy layout for the whole game. expect new challenges and surprises as you play through.

This game makes me think of what Zelda a Link to the Past for SNES would have been like today; regarding DS2's open world, limited hand holding and direction that makes exploration all that much more fun. Do I go and fight this boss or this boss first? Should I risk my souls and fight a harder boss for that really awesome piece of gear that will make my build..? Maybe! It reminds me that a good game doesn't need to be mindless and that the best reward is still overcoming a real challenge.  PROS: - Great community - Great PVP with a lot of replay value - Top notch story and atmosphere - For the player that pays attention and explores, the lore runs deep in this game. - Responsive controls (Controller ONLY, PC controls are terrible...  CONS: - It's clearly a port from XBOX as they didn't even take the time to change icons... very ugly but not enough to warrant not playing at least once. - Graphics are not as crisp as Bloodborne or WItcher but it came out before the new consoles so it's to be expected and at least the SOTFS version has updated textures. Additionally, although the graphics/textures may not be as good as Bloodborne/Witcher, the atmosphere/fun/game-play/reward that is created will surpass the need to have just slightly better graphics.

In short, it contains all DLC for DS2, new enemy placements, and a over all better game. Definitely harder than the first in areas, but in others, it is a bit more forgiving. Slightl graphical and audio upgrades also improve the look and feel of the game. It really feels like the definitive way the game was meant to be played. Very much recommeded, whether you are new to the Souls series or not.

CONS:  - The game lacks a good tutorial and does not explain the anything very well. Dark Souls 2: Scholar of the First Sin is the definitive version of this game. If you’re looking to buy the game, this is the version to get. This version has all of the DLC, better lighting, and many general changes that are too numerous to list here. From Software gets a huge demerit from me for the butchered release schedule of this game, which kind of screwed over people who had bought in to the new game, and the fact that the different versions of the game split the multiplayer up into different populations is another negative thing. I felt it important to mention that this happened in order for folks to be aware in the future, however I don’t hold the bad management of this game against it.  I’m not going to go in to the basics of the Souls series, because I figure you kind of have to know them by this point. If you’re curious, I vouch for starting from the first game (Dark Souls 1) and working your way up. There is a ton of content in Dark Souls 1 to keep you busy for a long time, and if you love this style of game you’ll be thirsty for more.  Dark Souls 2 is very different from the first game, and it is difficult to say whether these changes are for better or for worse. There were a few personnel changes under this game, and it really does show. The general game runs very well compared to Dark Souls 1, and if you have a decent PC you’ll be pulling 60 FPS compared to Dark Souls 1 being locked at 30.   At points, it feels like the game opts to be hard, rather than challenging, and although the Souls series is known for difficulty, I think it has always been challenging and fair. Dark Souls 2 has a number of moments that are blatantly unfair and frustrating. It really feels like the developers intended you to be summoning phantoms in a lot of areas. One area that comes to mind involves you wading through waist-deep water which slows you down, fighting monsters that are hidden under water, and dodging ranged spell attacks all at once. It’s frustrating to be the only target and I found myself hoping to find phantoms to summon to help me through each area. The game would suddenly get much more fun when I had a second person around to be a target and help deal with the huge packs of monsters the game throws at you.  I must criticize how this game supplements combat difficulty by adding more enemies to encounters, rather than making interesting enemies. The enemies will also pivot 360 degrees and track your movements, which both looks goofy and makes dodging a lot more frustrating.  There are way more levels in this game than the first, but the levels don’t really fit together in a cohesive manner. The world, in fact, is very disconnected and there isn’t much thought put in to the design compared to DS1. Things feel disjointed and strange, but there is a huge variety in level design that wasn’t present in the previous game.   The world is very detailed, and you’ll learn a lot just by slowing down and looking around.   There have been a number of YouTube personalities who have done their own analyses of this game, and if you’re interested in a more granular approach to the problems this game has, I’d advise you to seek them out. However, these are rife with spoilers.  I think this is a good game, but it has left me feeling frustrated at times. I wish there were more people playing, but it is kind of an old game at this point so the lack of population is not surprising. I found myself summoning a lot of phantoms, or hoping to be summoned to grind up some levels. I didn’t talk about PVP much here, but I can confirm that it is pretty active if you seek it out.

After buying a proper gaming pc and discarding my old poptart of a laptop i've changed my view on this game's new HD upgrade. Simply adding more enemies to make the playerbase happy is not an adequate way to satisfy their needs and wants for a more naturally difficult experience.  That being said, Dark Souls 2 was a good game in the way that it adds obscure flavor to the mix, for better or for worse, regardless of how easy it was. I'm sick of all that 'B-team this, B-team that' bull.  At least Dark Souls II is its own game! It's not a lazy homage fest like Dark Souls 3 which has a statue in criticland. Sure, both have their references, but 'A-team' Dark Souls 3 didn't even bother to   hide the Claymore in a different place!   From Soft. was so 'scared' of making another 'atrocity' like DSII that they basically made a Dark Souls 1 reskin of Bloodborne. That is what mob psychology does to games.  Dark Souls 2 improves on a load of things, like variety of weapons, armor and character builds, actually competitive caster classes, built-in challenges for end-game, playable PvP etc. The only objective complaints that can be made, we have heard a thousand times. It's about the level design not quite bringing the magic back from the original. Also, some people may find that a few areas offer only 'cheap' difficulty, especially in the (now included) DLC.  The changes made in the Scholar of the First Sin edition are minor. There was a one-year gap between my playthrough of the stock version and I can say the differences are rarely noticeable. It's mainly about blocking off some of the areas in the game to avoid confusion for new players and make the game more challenging for the old players. Some enemy and item placements have been changed, usually for the best. Finally, the graphics were supposedly improved.  Personally, I have put way more hours in this game than in the rest of the series and for good reason, though I won't deny that the true magic of Souls shines in the original Dark Souls. But after you're done with that, drop anchor in this one. You needn't go any further.  If all 'bad games' were like this, I feel the games industry would be MILES ahead right now.

It may not have the genuine depth or masterful level design of Dark Souls due to its rocky development, but Dark Souls 2 is still a supremely fun game, and Scholar of the First Sin is a gorgeous complete edition.

The combat in this game is fantastic, and is the centerpiece of the game. You have a wide variety of classes and weapons types at your disposal, and each weapon type truly allows for an incredibly different playstyle from the others. The melee combat is where this game shines and is truly what the franchise is based upon, but there are also “safer” methods of play with ranged magic or bow builds (which you get wrecked with if you ever play PvP).   The online combat is also terrifying and fantastic, as you could be on your last legs trying to get to the next bonfire with 20k souls when you get the notification that “dEEzeNuTZ69 has invaded your world.” You best run like the dickens son. Overall, the game has fantastic combat with a gorgeously designed world and story. Things aren’t shoved down your throat (expect arrows and swords and fire and metal), and you have the option to discover the rich lore and story or just say “bunk that” and just go off and adventure. This was a great entry point in the Souls franchise for me, and I will be a lifelong fan of this series.   10/10 would lose over a million souls again

As a big fan Soulsborne, I really wanted to enjoy this game as much as I enjoyed Dark Souls and Bloodborne. I had to learn the game all over again. After the first 10 hours of the frustration from the changes in game mechanics, I started to like it.  Dark Souls 2: Scholar of the First Sin is a really beautiful game, just like the first one. Didn't really like the art style, for whatever reason it didn't really get to me as it did for the first game. PC Port for this one was way better than Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition for PC, which is one of the thing that immediately made me enjoy the game more. The game is, once again, typical Souls game: Hard, but fair. However, there were lots of times when the game felt cheap because of the changes that came with the Scholar of the First Sin. I haven't played the vanilla version of the game, but I've heard from other players that the vanilla version was way easier, and they decided to add more enemies, make them 'smarter', and they added enemies from other locations on areas to make it more challenging. There are way more bosses in this game than there were in the first Dark Souls, but almost every one of these bosses lack the spirit that Dark Souls 1's bosses had. Their design is alright, most of them feel lazy, they feel like From Soft didn't have any new ideas. There were couple of them that were actually really good, but overall they could've been much better. Areas in this game are not really connected as they were in the first game (except for Majula, Iron Keep and its neighbour areas). The thing I really disliked about game's locations is the lack of creativity, once again.  Once again, this game also has lots and lots of items, and the content is pretty good.   Crown DLCs are quite enjoyable. Areas are well designed, they've certainly upped the difficulty in all three DLCs. Most of the bosses are exceptionally good, better than any in the main game.     Overall, I would give this game 8/10. It is definitely a great game, but it didn't live up to my expectations. If you are looking to buy it, I would still suggest that you get the first Dark Souls and make it work with mods, it isn't so hard. If you already did that, this game is a good game to play while waiting for Dark Souls 3, or if you want more Dark Souls as I did. I am really looking forward to Dark Souls 3, as it is going to combine the best things from the franchise. Miyazaki didn't work on Dark Souls 2, which is probably why it feels this way, but he is back for Dark Souls 3. Hopefully, Dark Souls 3 will be on the same boat as Demon Souls, Dark Souls and Bloodborne are in terms of quality of the game. This review will probably be lost in the sands of other reviews, but I thought I'd put my thoughts out here anyway.  Overall, the game is a little more difficult to learn if you aren't using a controller. It isn't because controllers are convenient, but because quite literally all of the tutorials are showing you how to play- using the controller format. Come to think of it, it isn't limited to the tutorials, it's true for everything. If you want to learn everything for yourself, you can just skip this next part.   I learned the hard way that Space is 'B', Enter is 'A', and E is 'X'. I still haven't figured out 'Y'.   Luckily, the first area is kind of like a 'safe haven' where you can try to learn these controls on your own.  The game itself rewards the cautious and alert. I've saved myself dozens of times because I looked both ways before crossing a room, or realized that item next to a corner is probably a trap. Of course, to learn 'that item is probably a trap', I had to die or nearly die to a similar situation. This is where the next paragraph comes in.  The game also gives you many chances to learn the area around you, learn the AI of an enemy, or notice patterns. If you die or rest at a bonfire, all enemies respawn in the exact same area, in the exact same state. Things technically don't get easier, but because of this it feels like it does once you go through the same area enough times.  Anyway, aside from the game expecting you to use a controller, I really don't mind. I know it looks like I haven't played this very long, but that's because I typically play offline at this point in time. Not sure if that'll change in the near future, but it won't matter because this review will be lost in the sea of other reviews.
